lead_paragraph: To stop the advance of the Islamic State’s potent Libyan branch, the United States and its allies have sought potential ground forces in a patchwork of militias.

byline.contributor: Suliman Ali Zway reported from Tripoli, Kareem Fahim from Cairo, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. David D. Kirkpatrick contributed reporting from London.
byline.original: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY, KAREEM FAHIM and ERIC SCHMITT

snippet: To stop the advance of the Islamic State’s potent Libyan branch, the United States and its allies have sought potential ground forces in a patchwork of militias.

headline.main: In Libya, U.S. Courts Unreliable Allies to Counter ISIS
headline.print_headline: Allies in Libya Prove Erratic Against ISIS

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

abstract: United States has been frustrated in its attempt to organize local Libyan militias into force that can combat rising threat of country's Islamic State branch, which is regarded as militant group's most dangerous affiliate; Libya lacks effective central authority, and US has been forced to choose from patchwork of unreliable groups; strategy comes with additional risk of inflaming local rivalries as Libya tries to recover from civil war.
